feed.title: NewsTracker: germanwings
feed.subtitle: This is a news tracking demo

entry.title: FAA had questioned mental health of Germanwings pilot
Germanwings plane evacuated after bomb scare
entry.summary: Lufthansa has faced questions about its pilot screening process since the March 24 Germanwings crash which appears to have been caused by a co-pilot who suffered from depression and deliberately steered the plane into a mountain.

entry.title: Germanwings crash: Lufthansa defends not reporting depression
entry.summary: German aviation industry doctors say that pilots should undergo more extensive medical checks in the wake of the Germanwings crash in the French Alps that killed 150 people.

entry.title: Germanwings crash: Aviation watchdog unaware of co-pilot Andreas Lubitz's medical history
entry.summary: Berlin: The German aviation authority did not know about co-pilot Andreas Lubitz's medical background prior to the Germanwings crash that killed 150 people, raising more questions over medical oversight of pilots.

entry.title: Psychological profiling, doors focus of French investigation [Photos] [Video]
entry.summary: BERLIN/PARIS - French air accident authority BEA said its probe into the Germanwings crash would study "systemic weaknesses" that might have led to the disaster, such as psychological profiling and cockpit door locks.

entry.title: Australia, after Germanwings disaster, mandates at least two people stay in cockpits
entry.summary: CANBERRA, Australia - Australia on Monday responded to the Germanwings air disaster by mandating that at least two crew members be present at all times in cockpits of larger domestic and international airliners.

entry.title: Horrifying transcript gives timeline of Germanwings plane crash in Alps
entry.summary: Germanwings and its parent company, Lufthansa, say they never received a sick note from Lubitz, suggesting he hid his illness from the airline.

entry.title: Germanwings crash families could seek damages in the US, lawyer says
German president: Germanwings crash an 'unbelievable horror'
Germanwings crash victims remembered [Photos]
entry.summary: COLOGNE, Germany - The passengers and crew killed in the Germanwings plane that crashed into the French Alps were remembered on Friday at a memorial service in which 150 candles were lit on the steps of the altar of Cologne Cathedral.

entry.title: Germanwings crash victims remembered with candles and angels
entry.summary: Lufthansa, the parent company of Germanwings, cancelled its 60th anniversary celebrations set for April following the disaster and set up screens showing live coverage of the memorial service at its main bases.

entry.title: Relatives, Leaders Mourn Germanwings Crash Victims At Memorial Service
entry.summary: Lufthansa, Germanwings' parent airline, took out full-page advertisements in many of the country's leading newspapers expressing sympathy and carried a livestream of the service on its website.

entry.title: Relatives, dignitaries remember Germanwings crash victims
entry.summary: A mourning ceremony is held in the Cathedral in memory of the 150 victims of the Germanwings plane crash last month in the French Alps.

entry.title: Cathedral service mourns victims from Germanwings crash
entry.summary: The Germanwings Airbus 320 was en route from Barcelona to Duesseldorf when it crashed in the French Alps on March 24, killing everyone aboard, including 72 Germans and 50 Spaniards.

entry.title: After Alps crash, Turkish Airlines CEO wants pilots to wed
entry.summary: ISTANBUL (AP) - Turkish Airlines' CEO says that pilots may not be as prone to destructive behavior like that of the Germanwings pilot believed to have intentionally crashed a flight last month - if only they get married.

entry.title: Germany holding memorial to mourn victims of Germanwings crash
entry.summary: "We really don't know what was going through his head during those deciding seconds, in the deciding minutes," Gauck said at the memorial, which was attended by German Chancellor Angela Merkel, ministers from Spain and France, and the heads of Germanwings and its parent airline, Lufthansa.

entry.title: Workers clear 80 percent of debris from Germanwings crash
Germanwings plane evacuated after bomb scare
entry.summary: Germanwings said the pilot of Flight 4U 826 to Milan was taxiing to the runway when he received a call from the air traffic tower at Cologne/Bonn airport to abort the flight.

entry.title: Germanwings plane evacuated after bomb scare
entry.summary: BERLIN (Reuters) - A Germanwings flight bound for Italy from Germany was evacuated late on Sunday due to a bomb threat, the airline said.

entry.title: Germanwings says plane evacuated at Cologne-Bonn airport after bomb threat received
entry.summary: The tower in Cologne alerted the pilot of the Airbus A320, which was taxiing toward the runway at the time, Germanwings said.

entry.title: Germanwings plane evacuated after police receive bomb threat
entry.summary: BERLIN (AP) " Germanwings says a plane headed for Milan was evacuated at Cologne-Bonn airport after German police received a bomb threat against the flight.

entry.title: Woman pretended to be Germanwings crash relative to get free flights: Reports
entry.summary: A woman allegedly pretended to be a cousin of a Germanwings crash victim to get free flights to the French Alps, according to German media reports.

entry.title: Germanwings plane crash: 'Fake relative' claims free flights to French Alps
Germanwings co-pilot may have spiked pilot's drink with diuretic, report says
Police probe if woman faked link to crash victim for flights
entry.summary: BERLIN (AP) - German police are looking into whether a woman claimed to be a relative of a victim of last month's Germanwings crash to get free flights to southern France.

entry.title: Airline official: Germanwings probe shouldn't set precedent
entry.summary: FILE - In this March 26, 2015 file photo, rescue workers work at debris of the Germanwings jet at the crash site near Seyne-les-Alpes, France.

entry.title: Airline industry official expresses concern about the handling of Germanwings investigation
Airline official: Germanwings probe shouldn't set precedent
entry.summary: "The circumstances of the investigation of the Germanwings accident have been highly unusual, and something that began as an accident investigation morphed into a highly public criminal investigation in which it seemed that every day new revelations were coming out," Tyler said.

entry.title: Airline official: Germanwings probe shouldn't set precedent
entry.summary: The subsequent investigation has focused in large part on the pilot's history of depression and procedures at Germanwings and its parent company, Lufthansa, for screening pilots for mental health issues.

entry.title: Airline official: Germanwings probe shouldn't set precedent
EU 'was looking at airline safety'
entry.summary: European Union authorities were looking in to German airline safety procedures on "a number of issues" well ahead of the March 24 Germanwings crash after a standard inspection by its aviation safety agency questioned some procedures.

entry.title: EU agency noted 'non-conformity? with Germany's air safety rules before Germanwings crash
Germanwings crash pilot's profile prompts questions, deep unease
entry.summary: The profile that has emerged of Germanwings co-pilot Andreas Lubitz has become more troubling by the day.

entry.title: France halts search for bodies at Germanwings crash site
Germanwings plane diverted to Stuttgart due to suspected oil loss
entry.summary: Germanwings said the pilots shut off one of the aircraft's engines and headed for Stuttgart when the problem was detected.

entry.title: Germanwings plane diverted to Stuttgart due to suspected oil loss
entry.summary:
FRANKFURT (Reuters) - A Germanwings flight to Venice was diverted to Stuttgart on Saturday as the Airbus A319 aircraft appeared to be losing oil, the airline said in a statement.

Germanwings flight 4U814, with 123 passengers and five crew members on board, took off from Cologne at 9.55 a.m. local time (0355 EDT).

entry.title: Germanwings co-pilot increased speed as jet went down
Germanwings co-pilot accelerated descent, French investigators reveal
entry.summary: PARIS -- The co-pilot of the doomed Germanwings flight repeatedly sped up the plane as he used the automatic pilot to descend the A320 into the Alps, the French air accident investigation agency said Friday.

entry.title: Germanwings co-pilot lied to doctors, Bild reports
entry.summary: Although Lubitz gave doctors information about his job as a pilot, and in some cases about his employer Germanwings, he deliberately concealed the fact that he was still working, the paper said.

entry.title: Germanwings co-pilot lied to doctors about sick leave: report
entry.summary: Germanwings parent Lufthansa said on Tuesday that when Lubitz resumed pilot training in 2009 he provided the flight school with medical documents showing he had gone through a "previous episode of severe depression".

entry.title: LUFTHANSA KNEW: Airline admits co-pilot reported depression in 2009 - VIDEO: Lufthansa admits it knew of co-pilot's 'depressive episode' - French Alps crash shows psychiatrists cannot be last line of defense
entry.summary: The Germanwings crash has already produced some changes in aviation procedures.

entry.title: Germanwings plane crash: passenger video 'found'
entry.summary: London: A video of the last moments on the doomed Germanwings plane has been found on a mobile phone memory card at the crash site in the French Alps, according to reports.

entry.title: Lufthansa flight school knew of crash pilot's depression
entry.summary: Psychiatrists and pilots have said there is no fail-safe test to spot suicidal pilots, but lawyers representing some of the families of victims of the Germanwings crash called on Tuesday for more regular psychiatric testing of pilots.

entry.title: Lufthansa crash pilot had told flight school of depression
entry.summary: BERLIN - The pilot believed to have deliberately crashed a Germanwings plane into the Alps last week had told officials at Lufthansa's flight training school that he had suffered from severe depression, the airline said.

entry.title: Lufthansa: Co-pilot told flight school of depressive episode
entry.summary: The revelation that officials Lufthansa had been informed of Lubitz's psychological problems raises further questions about why he was allowed to become a pilot for its subsidiary, Germanwings, in September 2013.

entry.title: French eye cockpit entry, psychological screening rules
entry.summary: Lufthansa - Germanwings' parent company - offered immediate aid last week of up to 50,000 euros ($54,250) per passenger to relatives of the victims.

entry.title: Lufthansa knew of Germanwings co-pilot's 'depressive episode' years ago
entry.summary: BEA said it aims to provide a "detailed analysis" of the Germanwings cockpit voice recorder and any other flight data - but it also plans to widen its search, to examine issues that could be problematic for all airlines.

entry.title: Families of victims of Germanwings plane crash could face up to four months waiting for loved ones remains to be identified?
entry.summary: The families of victims of the Germanwings plane crash face a wait of up to four months for the remains of their loved ones to be identified.

entry.title: Lufthansa CEO faces tough test after Germanwings crash
Germanwings co-pilot treated for suicidal tendencies years ago - prosecutors
Australia orders cockpit 'rule of two' after Germanwings crash
DNA of 78 Germanwings crash victims found
Germanwings Co-Pilot Never Submitted Sick Note, Airline Says
Germanwings flight 4U9525 crash: Investigators find torn up sick notes in Andreas Lubitz's home
Germanwings flight 4U9525 crash: Investigators find torn up sick notes in Andreas Lubitz's home
entry.summary: Police carry computer, a box and bags out of the residence of the parents of Andreas Lubitz, co-pilot on Germanwings flight 4U9525 in Montabaur, Germany.

entry.title: Germanwings plane crash: Lufthansa to require two people in cockpit at all times
entry.summary: Protocal overhaul: Lufthansa CEO Carsten Spohr says the Lufthansa Group, which includes Germanwings, Austrian Airlines, Swiss Air and Eurowings, will require two crew members to be in the cockpit at all times.

entry.title: Germanwings plane crash: Lufthansa to require two crew members in cockpit at all times
entry.summary: Berlin: Lufthansa said it will introduce new rules requiring two crew members to be in the cockpit at all times after one of the pilots at its Germanwings unit crashed a plane in the French Alps.

entry.title: Germanwings co-pilot may have hid illness from employers
entry.summary: Germanwings co-pilot Andreas Lubitz appears to have hidden evidence of an illness from his employers, including having been excused by a doctor from work the day he crashed a passenger plane into a mountain, prosecutors said Friday.

entry.title: French pilots suing over leaks in German jet crash probe
entry.summary: After leaks in the media about the crash, a prosecutor announced that cockpit recordings indicate the co-pilot of the Germanwings A320 jet intentionally flew the plane into a mountain.

entry.title: Germanwings co-pilot may have hidden illness
entry.summary: French investigators, who are in charge of the probe into the plane crash, believe the 27-year-old locked himself inside the cockpit and then intentionally smashed the Germanwings plane into a mountainside on Tuesday during a flight from Barcelona to Duesseldorf.

entry.title: German prosecutors: indications Germanwings co-pilot hid illness from employers
entry.summary: BERLIN (AP) - German prosecutors: indications Germanwings co-pilot hid illness from employers.

entry.title: Germanwings flight 4U9525 crash: captain reportedly tried to force way through cockpit door with axe
entry.summary:
Berlin: The captain locked out of the cockpit of the Germanwings plane that crashed in the French Alps reportedly used an axe to try to force his way back in.

Germanwings planes require an access code to open the door but the airline, which is owned by Lufthansa, did not wish on Thursday to give details "for security reasons".

entry.title: Germanwings co-pilot had serious depressive episode: Bild newspaper
Few precedents seen as Germanwings investigation points to deliberate crash
entry.summary: If Andreas Lubitz, Germanwings flight 9525's 27-year-old co-pilot, was determined to kill himself, he would not be the first to use an aeroplane as a tool for self-destruction or to kill others in the process.

entry.title: Germanwings plane crash: police find 'clue' at home of co-pilot Andreas Lubitz
entry.summary: Lubitz barricaded himself alone in the cockpit of Germanwings flight 9525 and apparently set it on course to crash into an Alpine mountain, killing all 150 people on board including himself, French prosecutors said on Thursday.

entry.title: Germanwings plane crash: how the cockpit door lock works
entry.summary: Evidence from the Germanwings cockpit voice recorder indicates that the co-pilot locked the captain out of the cockpit.

entry.title: Germanwings crash: other pilot-caused tragedies
entry.summary: German police carry boxes out of a house believed to belong to the parents of Germanwings co-pilot Andreas Lubitz on Thursday.

entry.title: Germanwings: Andreas Lubitz breakdown six years ago offers clue
entry.summary:
Mr Radker last saw Lubitz last autumn, when the Germanwings pilot returned to the club to renew his light aircraft flying licence and to take part in the club's barbecue, which he attended with a girlfriend.

Carsten Spohr, the chief executive of Lufthansa, Germanwings' parent company, said that Lubitz "took a break in his training six years ago. Then he did the tests [technical and psychological] again. And he was deemed 100 per cent fit to fly."

entry.title: Germanwings: Andreas Lubitz breakdown six years ago offers clue
entry.summary: Yet, in what Chancellor Angela Merkel described as a "new, simply incomprehensible" dimension to the Germanwings air disaster, it appeared that Lubitz was responsible for the deaths of 149 people.

entry.title: German co-pilot crashed plane wilffully: prosecutor
entry.summary: Lufthansa's chief executive said on Thursday he was stunned by the assumption that the co-pilot of a Germanwings jet deliberately crashed it into a mountain in the Alps.

entry.title: Co-pilot was 'very happy' with Germanwings job
entry.summary: Investigators enter the house where the co-pilot of the crashed Germanwings airliner jet is supposed to have lived in an apartment, in Duesseldorf, Germany, Thursday March 26, 2015.

entry.title: Germanwings Flight 9525 co-pilot said to be "happy" with his job
entry.summary: After completing his training, he spent an 11-month waiting period working as a flight attendant before becoming a co-pilot on the Germanwings A320 fleet.

entry.title: Germanwings plane crash: co-pilot Andreas Lubitz was 'happy he had the job' with airline
entry.summary:
Montabaur, Germany: Co-pilot Andreas Lubitz was silent as Germanwings Flight 9525 from Barcelona to Dusseldorf descended for eight minutes before crashing in the French Alps on Tuesday, authorities said.

A sign reading'Crash landing path' stands next to field at the LSC Westerwald flight club in Montabaur where the Germanwings co-pilot Andreas Lubitz had been a member.

entry.title: Co-pilot appears to have crashed Germanwings plane deliberately: Prosecutor [Photos] [Video]
entry.summary:
The CEO of Lufthansa, parent company of Germanwings, said its air crew were picked carefully and subjected to psychological vetting.

The co-pilot suspected of deliberately crashing a Germanwings jet into the French Alps on Tuesday has been identified as 28-year-old Andreas Lubitz.

Family members of passengers killed in Germanwings plane crash are escorted by a helper as they arrive at Barcelona's El Prat airport on March 24, 2015.

entry.title: Germanwings Co-Pilot Was 'Very Happy' With Germanwings Job
entry.summary:
MONTABAUR, Germany (AP) - Andreas Lubitz never showed any sign he was anything but thrilled to have landed a job with Germanwings, according to those who taught him the trade as a teenager in this town in the woody hills of Western Germany.

On Thursday, French prosecutors said Lubitz, the co-pilot of Germanwings Flight 9525, "intentionally" crashed the jet into the side of a mountain.

After starting his job with Germanwings in September 2013, Lubitz was upbeat when he returned to the LSC Westerwald e.V glider club in the fall to renew his glider pilots' license with 20 or so takeoffs.

Club chairman Klaus Radke said he rejected Marseille prosecutors' conclusion that Lubitz put the Germanwings flight intentionally into a descent and dove it into the French Alps when the pilot had left the cockpit.

entry.title: Co-pilot was ?very happy' with Germanwings job
entry.summary: "He was happy he had the job with Germanwings and he was doing well," said longtime club member Peter Ruecker, who watched him learn to fly.

entry.title: Germanwings co-pilot likely crashed jet deliberately: prosecutor
entry.summary: PARIS (Reuters) - The co-pilot of a Germanwings jet that went down in the French Alps, killing 150 people, appears to have crashed the plane deliberately, a Marseille prosecutor said on Thursday.

entry.title: Germanwings co-pilot appears to have crashed plane deliberately ? prosecutor
entry.summary: The Germanwings co-pilot was identified as Andreas Lubitz.

entry.title: Official: 1 pilot locked out of crash plane cockpit
entry.summary: The captain had more than 6,000 hours of flying time and been Germanwings pilot since May 2014, having previously flown for Lufthansa and Condor, Lufthansa said.

entry.title: Official: 1 pilot apparently locked out of cockpit before Germanwings plane crashed
entry.summary: PARIS - An official with knowledge of the audio recordings from the Germanwings flight that crashed in the Alps says one of the pilots apparently was locked out of the cockpit when the plane went down.

entry.title: Germanwings crash: pilot locked out of plane's cockpit, say reports
entry.summary: The co-pilot joined Greenwings in September 2013, directly after training, and had flown 630 hours, Lufthansa, the parent airline of Germanwings, said.

entry.title: Germanwings plane crash: possible to lock co-pilot out of cockpit

entry.title: Germanwings plane crash: A320 pilot says co-pilot can be locked out of cockpit
entry.summary: The New York Times has reported, citing an official involved in the Germanwings crash investigation, that the cockpit voice recorder shows one of the pilots had left the flight deck and could not regain entry.

entry.title: Germanwings plane crash: pilot locked out of cockpit
entry.summary: Voice recordings recovered from one of the black boxes from the downed Germanwings flight 4U9525 reportedly reveal fresh clues to the plane's demise.

entry.title: Details of victims in the crash of Germanwings Flight 9525
entry.summary: A Spanish opera house said Tuesday, March 24, 2015 German contralto Maria Radner along with her husband and baby, were among the 150 victims of the Germanwings plane crash in the French Alps.

entry.summary: This is an undated image of Paul Andrew Bramley who died in the Germanwings plane crash provided by his family Wednesday March 25, 2015.

entry.title: Details of victims in the crash of Germanwings Flight 9525
entry.summary: Bramley who originally came from Hull in England died on Germanwings flight 4U9525 which crashed in the southern French Alps on Tuesday.

entry.title: Germanwings crash: clue from cockpit recorder
entry.summary: One of the black box flight recorders from the Germanwings flight 9525 that crashed in the French Alps on Tuesday killing all 150 people aboard has been recovered at the site.

entry.title: Cockpit voice recorder hoped to unravel 'inexplicable' Germanwings crash
entry.summary: Germanwings said it had canceled one flight on Wednesday and was using 11 planes from other carriers for about 40 flights after some of its crew members had refused to fly.

entry.title: The Latest: Crashed jet's late takeoff was due to congestion
entry.summary: The director of France's aviation investigative agency says there currently is not the "slightest explanation" for what caused the Germanwings plane to lose altitude and crash in the Alps.

entry.title: Germanwings Investigation: How Will They Figure It Out?
entry.summary: NEW YORK (AP) - Cockpit voice recordings and, hopefully, flight data will provide the main clues to investigators trying to understand what caused Germanwings Flight 9525 to crash.

entry.title: How investigators will determine why Germanwings jet crashed
Team narrowly escaped doomed Germanwings flight
entry.summary: The players of Swedish soccer team Dalkurd narrowly escaped boarding the budget airline Germanwings' A320 that crashed in the French Alps killing all 150 people on board.

entry.title: Germanwings flight 4U9525 disaster: Laborious 'black box' inquiry aims to unlock crash cause
entry.summary: One of the Germanwings Airbus A320's two 'black boxes' was found hours after Tuesday's crash and will come under scrutiny at the spartan offices of France's Bureau d'Enquete d'Accidents (BEA, or office of accident investigations.)

entry.title: Germanwings flight 4U9525 disaster: Laborious 'black box' inquiry aims to unlock crash cause
entry.summary: This photo provided in Paris by the BEA, the French air accident investigation agency, shows the damaged voice data recorder of the Germanwings jetliner that crashed on Tuesday in the French Alps.

entry.title: Germanwings flight 4U9525 disaster: Laborious 'black box' inquiry aims to unlock crash cause
entry.summary: Germanwings said 72 Germans were killed in Tuesday's crash, the first major air passenger disaster on French soil since the 2000 Concorde accident just outside Paris.

entry.title: Germanwings CEO: Plane victims included 72 German citizens, 35 Spaniards, 2 Americans
entry.summary: COLOGNE, Germany (AP) " Germanwings CEO: Plane victims included 72 German citizens, 35 Spaniards, 2 Americans.

entry.title: Germanwings Cancels Flights After Crew Members Decide Not to Fly
Germanwings plane crash: Melbourne family of Carol and Greig Friday 'crippled with sadness'
entry.summary: A Melbourne family is "crippled with sadness" after mother and son Carol Friday and Greig Friday were among the 150 killed when Germanwings flight 4U9525 came down in southern France.

entry.title: Searchers recover black box from site as mystery over deadly plane crash in France deepens
entry.summary: "We cannot say at the moment why our colleague went into the descent, and so quickly, and without previously consulting air traffic control," said Germanwings' director of flight operations, Stefan-Kenan Scheib.

entry.title: Germanwings plane crash: Melbourne mother and son killed on board flight 4U9525
entry.summary: The location of the Germanwings flight 4U9525 crash in the French Alps.

entry.title: The Latest: Germanwings forced to cancel 7 flights
entry.summary: French Interior Minister Bernard Cazeneuve says 10 helicopters and a military plane have been mobilized to the site in the French Alps where a Germanwings plane crashed en route from Barcelona to Duesseldorf.

entry.title: Germanwings cancels seven flights as crews too upset to fly after tragic crash
entry.summary: "One must not forget: many of our Germanwings crews have known crew members who were onboard the crashed plane," Carsten Spohr said.

entry.title: The Latest: CEO: Details about plane crash should come soon
entry.summary: It said there will be a minute of silence before kick-off for the 150 people who died when a Germanwings plane crashed in the French Alps en route from Barcelona to Duesseldorf.

entry.title: Germanwings crash: Just how safe is the Airbus A320?
entry.summary: The passenger flight run by German airline Germanwings from Barcelona to Dusseldorf, Flight 9525, was carrying six crew members and 144 passengers, including a group of 16 schoolchildren, all of whom are now presumed dead.

entry.title: Germanwings crash: Just how safe is the Airbus A320?
entry.summary: Germanwings Airbus A320 plane crashes in French Alps, killing all on board Australian podiatrist Phillip Vasyli stabbed to death in Bahamas Germanwings crash: Just how safe is the Airbus A320?

entry.title: Crash is Germanwings' first fatal accident since 2002 start
entry.summary:
Germanwings, which has a fleet of around 78 aircraft flying to 130 destinations, plays a key role in Lufthansa's effort to compete against low-cost carriers such as Easyjet and Ryanair.

The Germanwings brand will be merged into Eurowings later this year for sales purposes, the airline says, although passengers will still see planes painted with Germanwings markings for the time being and Germanwings flight codes will remain.

entry.title: Crash is Germanwings' first fatal accident since 2002 start
entry.summary: Lufthansa says better results at Germanwings, along with lower fuel costs, should boost earnings for its airlines division - which also includes Swiss, Eurowings, Lufthansa CityLine, Air Dolomiti and Austrian Airlines - this year.

entry.title: Crash is Germanwings' first fatal accident since 2002 start
entry.summary: Meanwhile, Germanwings' parent company, Lufthansa, has not recorded a passenger fatality since 1993, when another Airbus A320 overshot a runway in Warsaw, Poland, killing one crew and one of 64 passengers.

entry.title: Why Germanwings flight might have crashed over the Alps
entry.summary: Germanwings Flight 9525 from Barcelona, Spain, to Duesseldorf, Germany, was flown on an Airbus A320, a workhorse of modern aviation, similar to the Boeing 737.

entry.title: Black box from Germanwings crash in French Alps found: minister
entry.summary: SEYNE-LES-ALPES, France (Reuters) - French Interior Minister Bernard Cazeneuve said on Monday that one of the black boxes from the Germanwings plane that crashed in the Alps has been found.

entry.title: The Latest: Spanish woman, baby among plane crash victims
entry.summary: A German official says a high school group returning from an exchange in Spain was on board the Germanwings plane that crashed in the French Alps, killing all 150 people onboard.

entry.title: French plane crash is first fatal accident for Germanwings, Lufthansa's low-cost unit
entry.summary: FRANKFURT, Germany - Germanwings, a low-cost unit of Lufthansa, had recorded no accidents involving passenger deaths until one of its planes crashed in the French Alps on Tuesday, killing all 150 on board.

entry.title: German Students Among Victims Of French Alps Plane Crash
entry.summary: PARIS, March 24 (Reuters) - A Germanwings jetliner that crashed in the French Alps on Tuesday did not issue a distress call during its rapid descent, France's aviation regulator said.

entry.title: Germanwings says had no problem with crashed plane before takeoff
entry.summary: COLOGNE, March 24 (Reuters) - Germanwings said it was unclear what caused its Airbus A320 aircraft to crash in the French Alps on Tuesday but that there had been no problems with the plane before takeoff.

entry.title: Plane carrying 150 went into 8-minute descent before crash in Alps
entry.summary:
French emergency services workers, back, and members of the French gendarmerie gather in Seyne in southeastern France on March 24, near the site where a Germanwings Airbus A320 crashed in the French Alps.

French President Francois Hollande said he believed none of the 148 people on board the Germanwings plane that crashed on Tuesday (March 24) had survived.

entry.title: Jet crashes in Alps with 150 aboard; no survivors expected
entry.summary: A worker from a Swissport, a Service Company who is handling for Germanwings airlines, gives information to a man who relatives were traveling in a crashed jet at an office in the Barcelona airport in Spain, Tuesday, March 24, 2015.

entry.title: Germanwings Airbus passenger plane crashes in French Alps
entry.summary: This Feb. 24, 2014, file photo shows a Germanwings Airbus A320 in front of the terminal at Koeln-Bonn airport in Cologne, Germany.

entry.title: Allianz lead underwriter for crashed Germanwings Airbus plane: sources
entry.summary: LONDON (Reuters) - Allianz is the lead insurance underwriter for the Germanwings Airbus A320 plane which crashed in France on Tuesday and AIG was another of the underwriters, insurance industry sources said.

entry.title: The Latest: Germanwings still awaiting info on crash
entry.summary: French President Francois Hollande has spoken briefly with German Chancellor Angela Merkel to express solidarity following the crash of a Germanwings plane in southern France.

entry.title: The Latest: French officials say debris from crash found
entry.summary: The CEO of Lufthansa, the parent company of Germanwings, says he doesn't yet have any information about what happened to its flight from Barcelona to Duesseldorf that French officials say has crashed in the Alps.

entry.title: Germanwings Airbus A320 crashes in French Alps
entry.summary: A Germanwings Airbus A320 operated by Lufthansa's Germanwings budget airline crashed in southern France on Tuesday en route from Barcelona to Duesseldorf, police and aviation officials said.

entry.title: 150 killed in French Alps aircrash
entry.summary: He said the captain on board was experienced and had been with the airline and with Germanwings' parent company Lufthansa for more than 10 years and had clocked up 6,000 flying hours on this particular Airbus model.

entry.title: Germanwings plane crashes in southern France - police
entry.summary:
Two Australians are confirmed as being among 150 people killed when an Airbus operated by Lufthansa's Germanwings budget airline crashed in a remote snowy area of the French Alps on Tuesday.

Smashed remnants of the Germanwings passenger jet scattered near Seyne-les-Alpes, French Alps.

Family members of people involved in the Germanwings plane crash comfort each other as they arrive at Barcelona airport in Spain.

entry.title: Germanwings plane crashes in southern France - police
Black box found at Germanwings plane crash site
entry.summary: The Airbus A320 operated by Germanwings, a budget subsidiary of Lufthansa, was less than an hour from landing in Duesseldorf on a flight from Barcelona when it unexpectedly went into a rapid descent.

entry.title: Plane crashes in French Alps with 150 on board
entry.summary:
The Germanwings logo, normally maroon and yellow, was blacked out on its Twitter feed.

The arrivals board shows flight 4U 9525 without a status at the airport in Duesseldorf, Tuesday, March 24, 2015, after the Germanwings passenger jet crashed in the French Alps as it traveled from Barcelona to Duesseldorf.

Germanwings planes at the airport in Cologne, Germany in 2014.

entry.title: No survivors of Germanwings crash in France, police say
entry.summary: Germanwings said the plane started descending one minute after reaching its cruising height and continued losing altitude for eight minutes.

entry.title: No survivors likely in Airbus A320 crash in French Alps
entry.summary: A Germanwings Airbus A320 with 144 passengers and six crew on board has crashed in the French Alps on Tuesday morning.

entry.title: The Latest: Germanwings says 150 aboard crash plane
